questions.text: A patient who has just recovered from COVID-19 infection visits your OPD with black discoloration material in nose and posterior part of buccal cavity. He also gives history of using high dose steroid therapy during his treatment of COVID-19. Which of the following is most suitable drug for his treatment? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Amphotericin B

 

The patient presents with symptoms indicative of mucormycosis, an opportunistic fungal infection that has become more common following COVID-19, particularly in patients who have received high-dose steroids. Mucormycosis is characterized by black necrotic lesions in the nose and posterior part of the buccal cavity, hence the term "black fungus."

 

Amphotericin B is the drug of choice (DOC) for mucormycosis. It is a potent antifungal agent that binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, creating pores that lead to cell death. This makes it effective against the Mucorales species responsible for mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is not effective against Mucorales species. It is typically used for treating Candida and Cryptococcus infections but not for mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Itraconazole: Itraconazole has antifungal properties but is not considered the first-line treatment for mucormycosis. It is used for infections caused by Aspergillus and dermatophytes but does not have the efficacy needed for mucormycosis.

 

Option D. Griseofulvin: Griseofulvin is used to treat dermatophyte infections of the skin, hair, and nails. It is ineffective against the fungi causing mucormycosis and is not relevant to this patient's condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drug of choice for treating mucormycosis, especially in patients who have received high-dose steroid therapy following COVID-19, is Amphotericin B. Mucormycosis presents with black necrotic lesions, hence the name "black fungus." Other effective drugs for mucormycosis include Posaconazole and Isavuconazole.

questions.text: Coagulation profile monitoring is needed in therapy with which of the following drugs? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lepirudin

 

Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor that is used in multiple doses and produces unpredictable effects, that has the most serious side effect of bleeding. Therefore, it requires monitoring by aPTT.

 

Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor, Enoxaparin is a LMWH that acts by inhibiting factor Xa and factor IIa, whereas Fondaparinux acts only by inhibiting factor Xa only.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fondaparinux: Fondaparinux is a selective factor Xa inhibitor that does not usually require routine coagulation monitoring because it has a predictable anticoagulant response when used at standard doses.

 

Option B. Enoxaparin: Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) that primarily inhibits factor Xa and to a lesser extent factor IIa (thrombin). Routine coagulation monitoring is generally not required with enoxaparin due to its predictable pharmacokinetic profile, though monitoring may be considered in certain populations (e.g., renal impairment, extremes of body weight).

 

Option C. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor that also does not typically require routine coagulation monitoring due to its predictable pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. However, in specific clinical situations, such as suspected overdose or emergency surgery, monitoring may be necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

:

Lepirudin, a direct thrombin inhibitor, requires regular monitoring of the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) due to its potential for unpredictable anticoagulant effects and the risk of serious bleeding.

questions.text: An anticancer drug, 5-Fluorouracil, causes thymineless death of cells. Which type of enzyme inhibition is responsible for this mechanism of action of 5-Fluorouracil? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive

 

5-Fluorouracil exhibits its anticancer effect through competitive inhibition. It is a thymidylate synthase inhibitor, competing with deoxyuridylate for the enzyme binding site. By inhibiting this enzyme, 5-Fluorouracil prevents the synthesis of thymidine, a nucleotide necessary for DNA replication, leading to thymineless death in rapidly dividing cells, like cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-competitive: Non-competitive inhibitors bind to an enzyme at a site different from the substrate's binding site, which is not how 5-Fluorouracil works.

 

Option C. Allosteric: Allosteric inhibition involves the binding of an inhibitor to an enzyme at an allosteric site, changing the enzyme's activity, which is different from 5-Fluorouracil's mechanism.

 

Option D. Irreversible: Irreversible inhibitors covalently bind to an enzyme, permanently inactivating it. 5-Fluorouracil, however, is a competitive inhibitor and not an irreversible one.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-Fluorouracil causes thymineless death of cancer cells through competitive inhibition of thymidylate synthase, blocking thymidine synthesis necessary for DNA replication in rapidly dividing cells.

choices.text: 5HT4 agonist
Dopamine antagonist

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prokinetic? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diphenylmethane

 

Diphenylmethane is not a prokinetic drug. It is a type of organic compound that is not used for the treatment of gastrointestinal motility disorders.

 

A prokinetic drug is a medication that increases gastrointestinal motility and promotes the movement of food through the digestive system. 5HT4 agonists, dopamine antagonists, and macrolides are all types of prokinetic drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5HT4 agonists stimulate the release of serotonin in the gut, which enhances gastrointestinal motility.

 

Option B. Dopamine antagonists block the action of dopamine in the gut, which can increase gastrointestinal motility.

 

Option C. Macrolides have antimicrobial properties and also act as motilin receptor agonists, which promote gastrointestinal motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphenylmethane is not a prokinetic drug and is not used to treat gastrointestinal motility disorders. Prokinetic drugs include 5HT4 agonists, dopamine antagonists, and macrolides, which all act to enhance gastrointestinal motility.

questions.text: A patient aged 45 years presents with swelling in MCP joints and his serum uric acid levels were found to be elevated. His physician prescribed a drug which is considered as the first line agent in the management of this condition. What is the mechanism of this drug? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Xanthine oxidase inhibitor

 

The clinical presentation of this patient is suggestive of gout, characterized by swelling in the MCP joints and elevated serum uric acid levels. Allopurinol is generally considered the first-line urate-lowering agent for gout. It works by inhibiting xanthine oxidase, an enzyme involved in the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and then to uric acid. By inhibiting this enzyme, allopurinol reduces the production of uric acid, thereby lowering serum urate levels and preventing gout flares.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibitor of neutrophil recruitment: Is Colchicine. It is indicated in Acute gout but is not considered as a first line drug as it can cause refractory diarrhea.

 

Option C. Uricosuric drugs: Are those which increase the excretion of uric acid in urine. These drugs are indicated in chronic gout. Examples include Lesinurad, Probenecid, Sulfinpyrazone etc.

 

Option D. Pyrimidine antimetabolite: Is a class of drugs used in cancer treatment. These drugs are structural analogs of pyrimidine nucleotides, which are essential building blocks for DNA and RNA synthesis. Examples include 5-Fluorouracil, Capecitabine, Cytarabine etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, is the first-line agent for lowering urate levels in the management of gout.

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed in case of an open angle glaucoma with bronchial asthma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Latanoprost

 

Latanoprost is a Prostaglandin, PGF2α analog, that acts in glaucoma by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor and is used as a first line drug in patients with open angle glaucoma. It can be safely used in bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that can cause bronchospasm as a systemic side effect. Therefore, it is not recommended for patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Option B. Gemeprost: Gemeprost is a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analog used for the termination of pregnancy. It is not relevant for the treatment of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Mannitol infusion: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used in the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma, not open-angle glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin F2α analog, is safe and effective for the treatment of open-angle glaucoma in patients with bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

questions.text: A patient was given 0.5% bupivacaine for brachial plexus block. After some time, the patient developed hypotension and cardiovascular collapse. What is the best treatment for this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 20% Intralipid

 

In the case of hypotension and cardiovascular collapse following a bupivacaine brachial plexus block, the recommended treatment is intravenous lipid emulsion therapy (e.g., 20% Intralipid). This treatment is specifically targeted at reversing the toxic effects of bupivacaine, which is a lipophilic local anesthetic. The other options, while useful in various cardiovascular emergencies, are not the primary treatments for bupivacaine toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: This is an antiarrhythmic medication used primarily for the treatment of certain types of serious arrhythmias. It's not typically used for the acute management of bupivacaine-induced cardiovascular collapse.

 

Option B. Epinephrine: This is a critical care drug used in the management of various life-threatening conditions, including anaphylaxis and cardiac arrest. It could be used in this scenario for its vasoconstrictive and positive inotropic effects, but it might not be the first choice due to the risk of exacerbating cardiac arrhythmias, which can be a complication of bupivacaine toxicity.

 

Option C. Dobutamine: This is a β1-selective vasoactive agent used primarily for the management of heart failure and cardiogenic shock. It increases cardiac output but would not be the first-line treatment for bupivacaine-induced cardiotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intralipid therapy is the recommended treatment for severe local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur with medications like bupivacaine. It acts by trapping lipophilic drugs like bupivacaine in an intravascular lipid emulsion, reducing their toxicity.

questions.text: DNA-Protein interactions can be studied by using: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNA footprinting

 

  • DNA footprinting is a technique used to study DNA-protein interactions. It involves the selective cleavage or modification of DNA sequences by a DNA-binding protein. By analyzing the resulting pattern of cleavage or modification, researchers can determine which regions of the DNA are bound by the protein, effectively "footprinting" its interaction sites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA fingerprinting: DNA fingerprinting is a technique used to identify individuals based on their unique DNA patterns, primarily in the context of forensic science and paternity testing. It is not specifically used to study DNA-protein interactions.

 

Option C. Northern Blotting: Northern blotting is a molecular biology technique used to study gene expression by analyzing the presence and quantity of specific RNA molecules in a sample. It is not primarily used to study DNA-protein interactions but rather RNA-related processes.

 

Option D. ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay): ELISA is an immunological assay used to detect the presence of specific antibodies or antigens in a sample. While it can indirectly provide information about protein-protein interactions, it is not a direct method for studying DNA-protein interactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA footprinting is the appropriate method for studying DNA-Protein interactions, as it allows researchers to identify the specific binding sites of proteins on DNA by selectively cleaving or modifying the DNA sequence. This technique is fundamental for understanding how proteins interact with DNA in various biological processes.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 451

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Oseltamivir and zanamivir? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neuraminidase inhibition

 

Both Oseltamivir and Zanamivir are antiviral medications used to treat influenza. They work by inhibiting the enzyme neuraminidase, which is critical for the release of new influenza virus particles from infected cells. By inhibiting this enzyme, these drugs limit the spread of the virus within the host.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA polymerase inhibition: This mechanism is typically seen in antiviral agents used to treat herpesviruses or other DNA viruses, not influenza viruses which are RNA viruses. Oseltamivir and Zanamivir are not DNA polymerase inhibitors.

 

Option B. Protein synthesis inhibition: These drugs do not act by inhibiting protein synthesis. Agents like tetracyclines or macrolides, which are antibiotics, usually have this mechanism of action.

 

Option C. Nucleotide analogue: While nucleotide analogues are commonly used to treat certain viral infections (e.g., acyclovir for herpes or antiretrovirals for HIV), Oseltamivir and Zanamivir are not nucleotide analogues. They do not incorporate into the viral genome to disrupt replication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oseltamivir and zanamivir are neuraminidase inhibitors used to treat influenza. By inhibiting the neuraminidase enzyme, these drugs prevent the release of new viral particles from infected cells, limiting the spread of the virus within the host.

questions.text: A female patient has been receiving first-line pharmacological treatment for bipolar disorder for 6 months. She is fasting for religious reasons and is experiencing seizures, coarse tremors, confusion, and limb weakness. Which of the following tests should be performed to help diagnose her condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum lithium level

 

The patient's symptoms of seizures, coarse tremors, confusion, and limb weakness are highly suggestive of lithium toxicity. Lithium has a very narrow therapeutic index, with toxicity often occurring at levels above 1.5 mEq/L. Fasting and dehydration can exacerbate lithium toxicity due to increased renal absorption of lithium, which occurs similarly to sodium under these conditions.

 

Given that the patient has been on first-line pharmacological treatment for bipolar disorder and her symptoms align with those of lithium toxicity, checking serum lithium levels is the most appropriate diagnostic step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum potassium level: While potassium imbalances can cause muscle weakness and arrhythmias, these are less likely to be the primary issue given the patient's history of bipolar treatment and her current symptoms. Potassium levels do not directly explain the symptoms related to lithium toxicity.

 

Option C. ECG: An ECG might be useful in some scenarios to identify heart issues, but it is less likely to provide insights into the patient's symptoms related to bipolar treatment and fasting. It is not the first-line diagnostic test for suspected lithium toxicity.

 

Option D. Serum sodium level: While fasting might affect sodium levels, the kidneys typically compensate to maintain serum sodium levels. However, this compensation also increases lithium reabsorption, leading to toxicity. Measuring serum sodium levels alone is unlikely to provide a definitive diagnosis related to her symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum lithium level should be checked in a patient receiving lithium therapy for bipolar disorder who presents with symptoms such as seizures, coarse tremors, confusion, and limb weakness, especially in the context of fasting or dehydration. This is crucial to diagnosing and managing lithium toxicity.

questions.text: An antiemetic was given to a chemotherapy patient, who then developed symptoms such as acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following medications would have resulted in these symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metoclopramide

 

  • Metoclopramide is an antiemetic and a prokinetic drug that acts by blocking the D2 receptors. It can be given IV and it can cross the Blood brain barrier, thereby leading to D2 receptor block in the brain which can have side effects like acute dystonia, abnormal movements and drug induced Parkinsonism.
  • In such cases, to treat them, drugs having central anticholinergic action like Benzhexol are used. They work by resorting the balance that has been disrupted by having a relative cholinergic excess in the striatum due to dopaminergic blockade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ondansetron: Ondansetron is a serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. It is commonly used as an antiemetic, especially in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, but it does not cause extrapyramidal side effects like metoclopramide. Its side effect profile mainly includes headaches, constipation, and QT prolongation.

 

Option C. Meclizine: Meclizine is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties, used primarily to treat motion sickness and vertigo. It does not block dopamine receptors and therefore does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Scopolamine: Scopolamine is an anticholinergic drug used to prevent nausea and vomiting, particularly motion sickness. It works by blocking acetylcholine receptors and does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms. Its side effects include dry mouth, dizziness, and blurred vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metoclopramide, an antiemetic that acts by blocking D2 receptors, can cause extrapyramidal symptoms such as acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors.

questions.text: A patient of colorectal cancer was treated with folinic acid, 5-fluorouracil and irinotecan therapy. He developed diarrhea following the regimen. Which of the following drug can be used for treatment of chemotherapy related diarrhea in this patient? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Loperamide
 

Loperamide drug can be used for treatment of chemotherapy related diarrhea in this patient.


Loperamide is an opioid agonist it can be used for the treatment of chemotherapy induced diarrhea. It acts by reducing the motility of the intestine as well as decreasing the intestinal secretions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atropine: It is added to loperamide like opioids to prevent the abuse potential.

 

Option C. Ciprofloxacin: it is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic which is effective in controlling bacillary diarrhea. Antibiotics play no role in treatment of post-chemotherapy diarrhea.

 

Option D. Metronidazole: It is an antibiotic which is effective against gram negative anerobes and parasitic infections. It is used in bacillary dysentery but not in post-chemotherapy diarhhea.


Educational Objective:

 

For the treatment of chemotherapy-induced diarrhea, particularly following regimens that include drugs like irinotecan, loperamide is the appropriate choice. Loperamide effectively reduces intestinal motility and secretions, helping to control and reduce diarrhea. Other medications such as ciprofloxacin and metronidazole are used for infectious causes of diarrhea and are not suitable for chemotherapy-induced cases.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient with alcoholic liver disease was given metronidazole for an infection. The next day, the patient presented with confusion, hallucinations, tremors, and agitation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium tremens

 

Explanation:


Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that typically occurs 48–96 hours after the last alcohol intake. It is characterized by confusion, tremors, hallucinations, agitation, and autonomic hyperactivity. The patient’s chronic alcoholism and abrupt discontinuation (or reduced intake) of alcohol likely triggered the condition, exacerbated by the stress of the underlying illness and treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Psychosis: Although alcohol-related psychosis can occur, the hallmark features of delirium tremens (hallucinations, agitation, tremors) align more closely with this scenario.

 

Option C. Disulfiram-like reaction: This condition, caused by the accumulation of acetaldehyde due to inhibition of acetaldehyde dehydrogenase (e.g., by metronidazole), typically results in nausea, vomiting, flushing, and hypotension, not confusion and hallucinations.

 

Option D. Alcohol withdrawal: While alcohol withdrawal can present with symptoms like nausea, anxiety, and tremors, delirium tremens represents a severe progression of this spectrum.

 

Educational Objective:


Delirium tremens is a life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal, presenting with hallucinations, confusion, and agitation, typically within 48–96 hours of reduced alcohol intake. Early recognition and management are critical to prevent fatal outcomes.

questions.text: A patient with gout develops hypertension. The uric acid level was found to be elevated. Which of the following is not administered? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that can lead to Hyperuricemia as its side effect. So, it should not be used in the management of hypertension in a patient with gout. The other side effects of thiazides include Hypokalemia, Metabolic alkalosis, Hyperglycemia, Hypomagnesemia and Hypercalcemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atenolol: Atenolol is a beta-blocker that does not typically affect uric acid levels and is considered safe for use in patients with gout.

 

Option C. Enalapril: Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor that does not increase uric acid levels and is suitable for managing hypertension in patients with gout.

 

Option D. Prazosin: Prazosin is an alpha-blocker that does not affect uric acid levels and can be safely used in patients with gout.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrochlorothiazide should not be used to manage hypertension in patients with gout due to its potential to increase uric acid levels and exacerbate the condition. Other antihypertensive drugs, such as beta-blockers (atenolol), ACE inhibitors (enalapril), and alpha-blockers (prazosin), do not have this adverse effect and are suitable alternatives.

choices.text: Teriparatide can be given along with bisphosphonates.
Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year
Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day
Oral vitamin D3 is given along with oral calcium

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal female patient with a history of Colle's fracture comes to the outpatient department complaining of lower back pain. After undergoing a bone density test, her T score is found to be -2.5. Which of the following statements about the management of her condition is incorrect? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year

 

This question deals with osteoporotic post-menopausal female, who has a history of fracture as well.

 

Bisphosphonates which act by inhibiting the bone resorption by the osteoclasts form the first line of treatment in this patient. Bisphosphonates are DOC for Osteoporosis (Steroid induced, post-menopausal and due to any reason). These are indicated for 5 years and then a drug holiday of 2-3 years is given to avoid adverse effects (increased risk of bone fractures and osteonecrosis of mandible). These can be repeated for another 5 years after drug holiday.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teriparatide can be given along with bisphosphonates: Teriparatide is a parathyroid hormone analog that stimulates bone formation by increasing osteoblast activity. It is particularly useful in patients with severe osteoporosis and a history of fractures. It can be started before bisphosphonates in certain cases.

 

Option C. Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day: The recommended daily intake of calcium for postmenopausal women is around 1200 mg. This helps maintain bone density and prevent further bone loss.

 

Option D. Oral vitamin D3 is given along with oral calcium: Supplementation with oral vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) along with calcium is essential to ensure proper calcium absorption and to maintain bone health. The recommended dose of vitamin D3 is typically around 800 IU per day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bisphosphonates are recommended for up to 5 years, not just one year, in the treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women.

choices.text: Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg HS for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam 500 mcg one tablet OD for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam ½ mg tablet HS daily

questions.text: As an Indian medical intern, which of the following is the correct format for prescription of alprazolam? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days

 

IMPORTANT POINTS REGARDING PRESCRIPTION WRITING:

 

  • Prescription is invalid without date and signature of the doctor.
  • Drug name should never been written in abbreviation form (e.g. never write PCM for paracetamol).
  • Abbreviations like OD, BD, HS etc should not be used in prescription.
  • Leading zeros should always be mentioned (e.g. 0.5 mg is correct but .5 mg is incorrect)
  • Trail zeros should never be written (e.g. 5 mg is correct but 5.0 is incorrect).
  • Microgram should be written as mcg not as µg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When writing a prescription, always avoid abbreviations for dosage instructions, use clear and complete language, include leading zeros for dosages less than one, and avoid trailing zeros. The correct format ensures clarity and safety for the patient.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the clinic for her annual check-up. Her DEXA scan shows evidence of osteoporosis with a T-score of -3.0 at the lumbar spine. She is postmenopausal and has no other significant medical history. She is interested in pharmacological treatment options for her osteoporosis. What is the first-line management for postmenopausal osteoporosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bisphosphonates

 

Bisphosphonates, such as alendronate and risedronate, are often considered the first-line therapy for postmenopausal osteoporosis. These drugs inhibit bone resorption and have been shown to reduce the risk of fractures in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrogen: While estrogen replacement therapy can be effective for preventing bone loss, it is generally not recommended as first-line treatment for osteoporosis due to potential risks, such as an increased risk of breast cancer, thromboembolic events, and cardiovascular disease.

 

Option C. Raloxifene: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that is sometimes used in osteoporosis treatment. It is not usually considered first-line treatment but may be an option for those who cannot tolerate bisphosphonates.

 

Option D. Combined Oral Contraceptives: Combined oral contraceptives are not used for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis. They are generally used in reproductive-age women for contraception and are not suitable for postmenopausal women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bisphosphonates are the first-line management for postmenopausal osteoporosis due to their effectiveness in inhibiting bone resorption and reducing fracture risk. Estrogen and raloxifene are alternative options but are not typically first-line treatments due to their associated risks and less robust efficacy compared to bisphosphonates. Combined oral contraceptives are not suitable for postmenopausal osteoporosis treatment.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are adverse effect of SGLT2 inhibitors? (AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

1. Ketoacidosis

2. Urosepsis

3. Fournier’s gangrene

4. Angioedema
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1, 2 and 3 are correct

 

SGLT-2 INHIBITORS

 

  • Sodium Glucose Transporter 2 (also called SGLT2)  is a transporter for reabsorption of glucose and Na+. It is present in PCT of nephrons. Drug inhibiting this transporter are Canagliflozin, Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin, Ertugliflozin etc.
  • By inhibiting the reabsorption of glucose, these drugs result in glucosuria. This can result in urinary tract infections (including Urosepsis) and genital tract infections like Fournier’s gangrene.
  • If used in type 1 diabetes, these decrease the blood sugar by causing glucosuria. The patient usually decreases the dose of insulin or may altogether stop using insulin as blood sugar levels are within required range. However, type 1 diabetes has absolute insulin deficiency. Insulin not only controls blood sugar but is also required for metabolism of ketone bodies. If the person stops using insulin, it may result in Ketoacidosis. Hence, SGLT-2 inhibitors are contra-indicated in Type 1 diabetes mellitus.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Angioedema: Angioedema is not a recognized adverse effect of SGLT2 inhibitors. This condition is more commonly associated with other drug classes, such as ACE inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary adverse effects of SGLT2 inhibitors include ketoacidosis, urosepsis, and Fournier's gangrene, while angioedema is not associated with these medications.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/301

questions.text: A psychiatric patient was started on lithium for the management of bipolar disorder. To monitor the blood lithium levels, at what time interval should the blood sample be collected after the administration of lithium tablets? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. After 12 hours

 

Lithium has a very narrow therapeutic index; therefore, the blood levels of lithium have to be monitored. Blood samples to measure lithium levels are typically collected 12 hours after the last dose. This timing is chosen because it represents the 'trough' level – the lowest concentration of the drug in the bloodstream before the next dose is due. Measuring at this point helps to ensure that the lithium level stays within the therapeutic range and avoids toxicity.

 

Plasma Levels of Lithium:

 

  • For prophylaxis of mania – 0.5 – 0.7 mEq/L
  • For acute mania – 0.8 – 1.2 mEq/L
  • Toxicity is seen when it is > 1.5 mEq/L
  • Dialysis is required at levels >4 mEq/L

 

Educational Objective:

 

To monitor lithium levels accurately and ensure they remain within the therapeutic range, blood samples should be collected 12 hours after the last dose. This helps in avoiding toxicity and ensuring the efficacy of the treatment for bipolar disorder.

questions.text: Following a hysterectomy, the patient received morphine for pain management both during the post-operative period and while in the ward. The current symptoms include respiratory depression and constricted (pinpoint) pupils. What would be the recommended medication for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Naloxone

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of opioid poisoning due to morphine, for which IV Naloxone can be administered.
  • In Morphine poisoning, the patient usually present in comatose state with low BP and heart rate as μ-receptor causes depression of brain including cardiovascular center.

 

SYMPTOMS OF OPIOID POISONING

 

  • Coma, respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils
  • Hypotension, bradycardia
  • Bradypnea
  • Hypothermia

 

ANTAGONISTS

 

  • Naloxone - Short acting, given iv
  • Naltrexone - Long acting, given Orally
  • DOC for acute opioid poisoning → Naloxone
  • DOC for maintenance in opioid poisoning → Naltrexone
    • Naloxone is added to oral opioids to reduce addictive potential.
    • Naltrexone is used to decrease craving in alcoholics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pethidine/Meperidine is a μ receptor agonist.

 

Option B. Atropine is an anticholinergic drug. Used in cases of organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option D. Buprenorphine is a partial μ receptor agonist and an antagonist at delta and kappa receptor. It has ceiling Effect on respiratory depression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naloxone is the drug of choice for treating acute opioid overdose, characterized by symptoms such as respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils, and coma. It acts rapidly to reverse the effects of opioids by competitively inhibiting their action at opioid receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effect is least likely to be associated with the use of amiodarone? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gynecomastia

 

Among the options given, gynecomastia is the least likely to be associated with the use of amiodarone. Hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, and pulmonary fibrosis are all recognized adverse effects of amiodarone, while gynecomastia is not typically linked to its use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Amiodarone can cause both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism due to its high iodine content and its effect on thyroid hormone synthesis and metabolism.

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: As mentioned above, hyperthyroidism is also a known side effect of amiodarone, along with hypothyroidism.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Fibrosis: Pulmonary fibrosis is a well-known and potentially serious side effect of amiodarone, likely due to its toxic effects on lung tissue and prolonged half-life.

 

Adverse Effects of Amiodarone can be remembered as:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gynecomastia is typically associated with drugs that affect hormonal balance. Drugs causing gynecomastia includes:

 

DI:        DIgoxin

S:         Spironolactone

C:         Cimetidine

O:        Oestrogens

questions.text: An individual with type 2 diabetes mellitus was prescribed a medication that lowered their HbA1C levels from 7.6 to 6.7. Subsequently, the person began experiencing discomfort characterized by itching in the vulvovaginal region. What is the probable medication that was initiated for this individual? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Canagliflozin

 

The patient complaining of itching in genital region after consuming a drug to lower down HbA1C levels is likely pointing to urogenital infection, which is a side effect associated with Canagliflozin (SGLT2 inhibitor).

 

SGLT-2 INHIBITORS

 

  • Glucose is freely filtered by glomerulus but the clearance of glucose in urine is negligible.
  • Because the reabsorption takes place in proximal tubule by sodium glucose transporter (SGLT-2)
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors stop the reabsorption of glucose in PT resulting in glucosuria.
  • Most common side effect of SGLT-2 Inhibitors is Urinary Tract infections (urosepsis) and genital Tract infections. (e.g., Fournier’s gangrene)
  • If gliflozins are taken by type 1 diabetes patients, it controls blood sugar level and makes it normal and then if the patients stop taking insulin, it will result in Ketoacidosis (as type 1 diabetes is characterized by complete deficiency of insulin)
  • SLGT-2 inhibitors provide cardiovascular benefits. These are approved for treatment of CHF.
  • Drugs are.
    • Canagliflozin
    • Dapagliflozin
    • Empagliflozin
    • Ertugliflozin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acarbose: This is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that primarily acts in the intestine to slow down the breakdown of complex carbohydrates. It is not usually associated with vulvovaginal itching.

 

Option C. Linagliptin: A DPP-4 inhibitor, Linagliptin is not typically associated with vulvovaginal itching or infections.

 

Option D. Liraglutide: This GLP-1 agonist is more commonly associated with gastrointestinal side effects rather than vulvovaginal itching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that lowers blood sugar by causing more glucose to be excreted in the urine. It is known for causing genitourinary infections, including vulvovaginal candidiasis, which can result in symptoms like itching and discomfort.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the prophylaxis of motion sickness? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promethazine

 

  • The drug that is used for the prophylaxis of motion sickness is Promethazine.
  • Promethazine is an H1 receptor antagonist with anticholinergic, sedative, and antiemetic properties. It works by blocking the action of histamine in the brain, reducing the symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and dizziness associated with motion sickness.
  • Other drugs used for the treatment of motion sickness include scopolamine (DOC), dimenhydrinate and meclizine, which also have antihistamine properties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cetirizine: Cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine primarily used for the treatment of allergic rhinitis, hives, and other allergic conditions. It lacks significant sedative and antiemetic effects and is not typically used for motion sickness.

 

Option C. Misolastine: Misolastine is another second-generation antihistamine used for allergic conditions but is not indicated for motion sickness due to its lack of sedative and antiemetic properties.

 

Option D. Loratadine: Loratadine is also a second-generation antihistamine used for allergic conditions. Similar to cetirizine and misolastine, it does not possess the sedative and antiemetic effects required to treat motion sickness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Promethazine is used for the prophylaxis of motion sickness due to its strong antihistamine, anticholinergic, sedative, and antiemetic properties. Second-generation antihistamines like cetirizine, misolastine, and loratadine are not effective for this purpose due to their lack of these properties.

questions.text: A patient presents with hypertension. He has a history of renal stones and has experienced a few episodes of renal colic. Which diuretic is the most appropriate to use? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that decreases calcium excretion in the urine by promoting calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron. This mechanism reduces the amount of calcium that is excreted into the urine, which lowers the risk of renal stone formation. Although thiazides can cause hypercalcemia by increasing calcium levels in the blood, they are beneficial in patients with a history of renal stones because they reduce urinary calcium levels, thereby decreasing the likelihood of stone formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that increases calcium excretion in the urine by inhibiting calcium reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This can lead to increased calcium in the urine, which raises the risk of renal stone formation, making it less appropriate for patients with a history of renal stones.

 

Option C. Ethacrynic acid: Similar to furosemide, ethacrynic acid is a loop diuretic that increases calcium excretion in the urine. Its use can also increase the risk of renal stones and is not the best choice for patients with a history of nephrolithiasis.

 

Option D. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that works primarily by antagonizing aldosterone in the distal nephron, leading to the retention of potassium and excretion of sodium. It does not have a significant impact on calcium excretion and is not indicated for reducing the risk of renal stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is the preferred diuretic in patients with a history of renal stones because it reduces urinary calcium excretion, thereby decreasing the risk of stone formation.

choices.text: Enoxaparin
Lepirudin
Fondaparinux
Dabigatran

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulant requires coagulation profile monitoring? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lepirudin

 

  • Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor that typically requires regular monitoring of anticoagulant effect via activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).
  • Enoxaparin (a low molecular weight heparin), Fondaparinux (a synthetic pentasaccharide), and Dabigatran (a direct thrombin inhibitor) generally do not require regular monitoring in most patients, although there may be specific clinical situations where monitoring is needed.

choices.text: Release of noradrenaline at synaptic cleft
Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors

questions.text: An elderly woman received a Botox injection for the treatment of wrinkles.  Which of the following is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibits the release of acetylcholine

 

  • The botulinum toxin works by preventing acetylcholine from entering the synaptic cleft. Acetylcholine is exocytosed by SNARE protein, which is broken down by botulinum toxin. Consequently, it prevents acetylcholine from being released.
  • Other agents that regulate the level of Ach in the synapse are:
    • Hemicholinium acts by inhibiting choline uptake (the rate limiting step in the synthesis of acetylcholine)
    • Vesamicol inhibits the uptake of Acetylcholine into the vesicles.
    • Physostigmine inhibits the breakdown of Ach at the synaptic cleft by the action of Acetylcholine esterase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Release of noradrenaline at synaptic cleft: Botulinum toxin does not facilitate the release of noradrenaline. Its primary action is on the cholinergic neurons where it inhibits the release of acetylcholine.

 

Option C. Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors: Botulinum toxin does not directly inhibit nicotinic receptors. Instead, it prevents the release of acetylcholine, which means there is no neurotransmitter available to bind to and activate the nicotinic receptors.

 

Option D. Stimulates muscarinic and nicotinic receptors: Botulinum toxin does not stimulate muscarinic or nicotinic receptors. In fact, it decreases neurotransmission by preventing the release of acetylcholine, which would otherwise stimulate these receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Botulinum toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine by cleaving SNARE proteins, thereby preventing neurotransmission at the neuromuscular junction and leading to muscle relaxation.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics is primarily excreted via bile and is safe for use in patients with renal failure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone

 

Explanation:


Ceftriaxone is primarily excreted via bile and does not require significant dose adjustment in patients with renal failure. This makes it safer for use in such patients compared to other antibiotics that are primarily cleared by the kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gentamicin: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside that is primarily excreted by the kidneys and requires dose adjustments in renal failure to prevent nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.

 

Option C. Amphotericin B: Although amphotericin B is not significantly renally excreted, it can cause nephrotoxicity, requiring careful monitoring and possible dose adjustments based on renal function.

 

Option D. Vancomycin: Vancomycin is predominantly renally excreted, and its dose must be adjusted in renal failure to avoid toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:


The drugs which are secreted in bile and safe in renal disease include:

 

Cef in: Cefoperazone, Ceftriaxone

 

The: Tigecycline 

R: Rifampicin

E: Erythromycin

N: Nafcillin

A: Ampicillin

L: Lincosamide (Clindamycin)

D: Doxycycline

questions.text: The replacement dose of hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 15-25

 

  • The replacement dose of hydrocortisone in adrenal insufficiency varies depending on the severity of the condition and the individual needs of the patient. However, the usual starting dose is 15-25 mg of hydrocortisone per day, divided into two or three doses.
  • For those with more severe adrenal insufficiency or during periods of stress, higher doses may be needed, up to 100-150 mg per day, also divided into two or three doses.
  • It is important to note that the replacement dose of hydrocortisone may need to be adjusted over time based on the patient's response to treatment and any changes in their medical condition. Therefore, patients with adrenal insufficiency should be regularly monitored by their healthcare provider to ensure they are receiving the appropriate dose of hydrocortisone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard replacement dose of hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency is 15-25 mg per day, divided into two or three doses to mimic the body's natural cortisol production. This dose may be adjusted based on individual patient needs and response to treatment.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of recurrent skin infections is admitted to the hospital for cellulitis. He has been treated with penicillin in the past but his current infection is not responding well to the treatment. The healthcare team suspects that the infecting bacteria may produce beta-lactamases and are considering alternative antibiotics. What is the mechanism of resistance by beta-lactamases to penicillins? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Degradation of antibiotics.

 

Beta-lactamases enzymatically degrade the beta-lactam ring of penicillin, rendering it inactive. This is the primary mechanism by which beta-lactamases confer resistance to penicillin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alteration of penicillin binding protein is a resistance mechanism seen in bacteria like MRSA (Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus) but is not the mechanism by which beta-lactamases confer resistance to penicillins.

 

Option C. Drug efflux is a different mechanism of antibiotic resistance where the bacteria pump out the antibiotics like tetracyclines, but it is not the mechanism for beta-lactamase resistance.

 

Option D. Alteration in the 50s ribosome structure is a mechanism of resistance against antibiotics that target the bacterial ribosome, such as macrolides, and is not relevant to beta-lactamase-mediated resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-lactamases confer resistance to penicillins by enzymatically degrading the beta-lactam ring of the antibiotic, rendering it inactive. This is the primary mechanism by which beta-lactamase-producing bacteria evade the effects of beta-lactam antibiotics.

questions.text: Most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Granisetron

 

Granisetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist that is highly effective for preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). These drugs have become the standard of care for managing moderate to highly emetogenic chemotherapy agents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Domperidone: Domperidone is a dopamine receptor antagonist used for the treatment of nausea and vomiting, but it is generally not as effective as 5-HT3 receptor antagonists like Granisetron for managing chemotherapy-induced vomiting.

 

Option B. Tegaserod: Tegaserod is primarily used for treating irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with constipation and is not an antiemetic. It acts as a 5-HT4 receptor agonist to promote gastrointestinal motility.

 

Option D. Doxylamine: Doxylamine is an antihistamine that can be used for nausea and vomiting during pregnancy, often in combination with pyridoxine (vitamin B6). It is not the most effective option for chemotherapy-induced vomiting.

 

Therefore, the most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting is Granisetron, making option C the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granisetron, a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist, is the most effective antiemetic for preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). It is the standard of care for managing nausea and vomiting associated with moderate to highly emetogenic chemotherapy agents.

questions.text: Which of the following is a second line anti-tubercular drug? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ethionamide

 

Ethionamide is used as a second-line treatment for tuberculosis (TB), particularly in cases of multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB), when the first-line drugs (like isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide) are not effective or cannot be used due to resistance or side effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: This is a first-line anti-tubercular drug, widely used in the treatment of both latent and active TB infections.

 

Option C. Acyclovir: Acyclovir is an antiviral medication, primarily used for the treatment of herpes simplex virus infections and not for tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Vancomycin: Vancomycin is an antibiotic used to treat serious bacterial infections caused by gram-positive bacteria, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). It is not used in the treatment of tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethionamide is a second-line anti-tubercular drug used in the management of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), whereas isoniazid is a first-line drug, and acyclovir and vancomycin are not used for tuberculosis treatment.

questions.text: A male patient is being treated for a mood disorder. After starting a new medication, he experiences priapism, a prolonged, painful erection. The healthcare provider is considering changing the medication. Which drug is most likely responsible for causing priapism in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Trazodone

 

Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant that is often used off-label for insomnia. It is known to cause priapism as a rare but serious side effect. Given that the patient has a mood disorder and experienced priapism, trazodone is the most likely culprit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Venlafaxine: This is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) used to treat depression and anxiety disorders. While sexual dysfunction is a potential side effect, it is not commonly associated with priapism.

 

Option C. Bupropion: This is an atypical antidepressant used for depression and smoking cessation. It is not commonly associated with priapism as a side effect.

 

Option D. Mirtazapine: This is another atypical antidepressant used for depression. It also has a low likelihood of causing priapism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trazodone is the most likely antidepressant to cause priapism among the listed options due to its known side effect profile. This serious condition necessitates careful monitoring and potentially switching medications to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A pituitary tumor that overproduced growth hormone was surgically removed from a patient. The resection was discovered to be insufficient. What is the patient's first-line treatment? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Octreotide

 

Octreotide is a synthetic somatostatin analog that inhibits the secretion of growth hormone (GH) from the pituitary gland. It is the first-line treatment for patients with acromegaly when surgery alone is insufficient to control GH levels. Octreotide binds to somatostatin receptors, reducing GH production and controlling symptoms of acromegaly.

 


Other Options:

 

Option A. Leuprolide: Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist primarily used in the treatment of hormone-sensitive cancers such as prostate cancer, and conditions like endometriosis and uterine fibroids. It is not used for reducing GH levels in acromegaly.

 

Option B. Goserelin: Goserelin is another GnRH agonist used for similar indications as leuprolide, including prostate cancer and breast cancer, as well as for managing endometriosis. It is not indicated for GH reduction in acromegaly.

 

Option C. Nafarelin: Nafarelin also a GnRH agonist, is used for the treatment of endometriosis and central precocious puberty. Like the other GnRH agonists, it is not used to manage GH levels in acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Octreotide is used for the treatment of the following conditions: (SOMATostatin)

 

S: Secretory diarrhea due to carcinoid tumor, VIPomas, following cancer chemotherapy, AIDS etc.

 

O: Oesophageal varices (Acute Variceal bleeding)

 

M: Malignancy like Insulinoma and Glucagonoma

 

A: Acromegaly due to GH secreting pituitary adenoma

 

T: Thyrotrope adenoma

 

  • Leuprolide, Goeserelin and Nafarelin are GnRH agonists.

questions.text: A female patient presented with pain and redness in great toe. Serum uric acid level is 9.6 mg/dL. Apart from prescribing analgesics for relieving pain, the physician prescribed a drug which can decrease the formation of uric acid. Which of the following enzyme is likely to be inhibited by this drug? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Xanthine oxidase

 

Uric acid is formed from the breakdown of purines in the body which are metabolized to form Hypoxanthine. Hypoxanthine is converted to xanthine and xanthine is ultimately converted to uric acid with the help of the enzyme Xanthine Oxidase. Thus, the drugs like Allopurinol and Febuxostat that act by inhibiting this enzyme can be used in the treatment of hyperuricemia and gout.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thymidylate synthase: Is the enzyme which is used in production of thymidine monophosphate (TMP) from deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP). It is targeted by 5-Fluorouracil.

 

Option C. Phosphoribosyl transferase: Is the enzyme that plays a critical role in nucleotide biosynthesis, specifically in the salvage pathway. It includes HGPRT and APRT. HGPRT deficiency is seen in an autosomal recessive disorder – Lesch Nyhan Syndrome.

 

Option D. DHFR or Dihydrofolate reductase is an enzyme which is involved in Folic acid metabolism by converting dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate. It is required for synthesis of thymine from uracil (methylation). It is targeted by Methotrexate, Trimethoprim, Pyrimethamine etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xanthine oxidase is the enzyme responsible for the final steps in the production of uric acid from purines. Inhibitors of xanthine oxidase, such as allopurinol and febuxostat, are used to reduce uric acid levels and are effective treatments for hyperuricemia and gout.

choices.text: Muscle fasciculations

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency room after poisoning with an unknown substance. Muscarinic poisoning was suspected and he was treated for the same. What is the possible presenting feature which led to the diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bradycardia
 

The types of Muscarinic receptors and their actions are as follows:

 

  • M1 – They increase the acid secretion in the stomach
  • M2 – They are present in the heart and lead to a decrease in heart rate (Bradycardia) and cause slowing of conduction in the AV node.
  • M3 – They are present in the respiratory tract and cause bronchoconstriction. They are also present in the urinary bladder, where they help in urination by bringing about contraction of the bladder. In the glands, these receptors help in secretion. In the eyes it leads to miosis.

 

Bradycardia is the possible presenting feature which led to the diagnosis of muscarinic poisoning in this case. Muscarinic poisoning occurs due to the consumption of poisonous mushroom-like Inocybe. Muscarinic symptoms appear within an hour of eating the mushroom. These symptoms (along with nicotinic symptoms) can also be seen in organophosphate poisoning. Atropine is used for the management of muscarinic poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mydriasis: This refers to pupil dilation, which is typically associated with sympathetic stimulation or anticholinergic effects, not muscarinic poisoning.

 

Option B. Diuresis: This refers to increased urine production, which is not a direct effect of muscarinic poisoning. Muscarinic activation actually increases bladder contraction, promoting urination.

 

Option C. Muscle fasciculations: These are more associated with nicotinic receptor activation, not muscarinic receptor activation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bradycardia is a key presenting feature that can lead to the diagnosis of muscarinic poisoning. Muscarinic receptors, particularly M2 receptors in the heart, mediate a decrease in heart rate. Atropine is used to manage muscarinic poisoning by blocking acetylcholine's action on these receptors.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a history of bipolar disorder has recently been started on lithium therapy. During a follow-up visit, the healthcare provider wants to educate the patient on the signs of lithium toxicity. Which of the following side effects should the patient be instructed to monitor and report immediately as they may indicate lithium toxicity? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ataxia and Diarrhea

 

Ataxia, tinnitus and diarrhea are common signs of lithium toxicity. Lithium has a narrow therapeutic range, meaning that the difference between a therapeutic dose and a toxic dose is small. Therefore, monitoring for signs of toxicity is crucial. Other signs of lithium toxicity can include tremors, confusion, and vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaise and sore throat: While these symptoms can be concerning, they are not typically associated with lithium toxicity. They might be indicative of an infection or other unrelated conditions.

 

Option C. Fever: Fever is not a common sign of lithium toxicity. It may indicate an infection or other illness.

 

Option D. Breathlessness: This symptom is not typically associated with lithium toxicity. Breathlessness might be related to other medical conditions such as respiratory or cardiac issues.

 

Therefore, patients on lithium therapy should be particularly vigilant for symptoms like ataxia and diarrhea, as they could indicate the onset of lithium toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients on lithium therapy should be educated to monitor and immediately report signs of lithium toxicity, such as ataxia and diarrhea, to prevent serious adverse effects.

 

Mnemonic

 

If DAT symptom is present, report to hospital:

 

  • Diarrhea
  • Ataxia
  • Tinnitus

questions.text: The given diagram shows the steps in bacterial cell wall formation. Identify the site of action of beta-lactam antibiotics. (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Beta lactams act on step 4 in the given image.

 

The beta lactams inhibit the formation of bacterial cell wall by inhibiting the Transpeptidase enzyme which is required for the cross linking of the peptidoglycan chains; therefore, they lead to a reduction in the strength of the bacterial cell wall which ultimately causes it to burst, leading to the death of the bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Fosfomycin inhibits step 1 in the image. It inhibits the cytoplasmic enzyme enol pyruvate transferase that catalyses the initial step in the bacterial cell wall synthesis. It is used for the treatment of urinary tract infections.

 

Option B. 2: Bacitracin inhibits step 2 in the image. It is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor that interferes with dephosphorylation of the BP transporter which transfers peptidoglycan subunits to the growing cell wall.

 

Option C. 3: Vancomycin inhibits step 3 in the image. It binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide. This prevents further elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking by inhibiting transglycolase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-lactam antibiotics act at step 4 in the bacterial cell wall synthesis process by inhibiting transpeptidase enzymes, which are essential for cross-linking peptidoglycan chains, thereby weakening the bacterial cell wall and causing cell lysis.

questions.text: Which is the drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sodium valproate

 

Sodium valproate is the drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea. It's an anticonvulsant medication that has proven effective in managing the involuntary movements associated with this condition. It works primarily by enhancing the effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain, which helps reduce abnormal electrical activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Probenecid: Probenecid is a medication used primarily to treat gout by reducing the levels of uric acid in the blood. It is not used for the treatment of rheumatic chorea.

 

Option B. Diazepam: Diazepam is a benzodiazepine used to treat anxiety, muscle spasms, and seizures. While it can provide muscle relaxation and sedation, it is not the drug of choice for managing refractory rheumatic chorea.

 

Option C. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication that can be used in some movement disorders. While it has been used in chorea, it is not considered the optimal treatment for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea due to its side effect profile and efficacy compared to sodium valproate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium valproate is the preferred drug for treating refractory intractable rheumatic chorea due to its efficacy in reducing involuntary movements by enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission in the brain. It has a better side effect profile for long-term management of this condition compared to other options.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drug is not bactericidal? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thioacetazone

 

Thioacetazone is a bacteriostatic anti-tubercular drug. Bacteriostatic drugs inhibit the growth and replication of bacteria, rather than killing them outright. Thioacetazone is less commonly used nowadays due to its side effects and the availability of more effective treatments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is a bactericidal drug against actively dividing Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid, a critical component of the bacterial cell wall.

 

Option B. Rifapentin: Rifapentin is a bactericidal antibiotic and is a derivative of rifampicin. It works by inhibiting bacterial RNA synthesis and is used primarily in the treatment of tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Kanamycin: Kanamycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic and is bactericidal. It works by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis. It is used as a second-line drug for the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thioacetazone is a bacteriostatic anti-tubercular drug, which means it inhibits bacterial growth rather than killing the bacteria outright. In contrast, isoniazid, rifapentin, and kanamycin are all bactericidal drugs used in the treatment of tuberculosis.

choices.text: Discoveries of molecular mechanisms controlling the circadian rhythm
Discovery of cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation
Discovery that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent

questions.text: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, 2018 was awarded to James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjo for which of the following discoveries? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Discovery of cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation

 

The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for 2018 was awarded jointly to James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjo for their pioneering work in cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation. Their research focused on understanding how the immune system can be harnessed to fight cancer, specifically through the mechanism of immune checkpoint inhibitors.

 

  • James P. Allison discovered that the protein CTLA-4 (cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated protein 4) acts as a brake on T cells. By inhibiting CTLA-4, it is possible to boost the immune system's response against cancer cells.
  • Tasuku Honjo discovered a different protein, PD-1 (programmed cell death protein 1), which also functions as an immune checkpoint. Blocking PD-1 can similarly enhance the immune system's ability to attack cancer cells.

 

These discoveries have led to the development of drugs known as immune checkpoint inhibitors, which have significantly improved treatment outcomes for various types of cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discovery of mechanisms of autophagy: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2016 was awarded to Yoshinori Ohsumi for his discoveries of mechanisms for autophagy, a fundamental process for degrading and recycling cellular components.

 

Option B. Discoveries of molecular mechanisms controlling the circadian rhythm: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2017 was awarded to Jeffrey C. Hall, Michael Rosbash, and Michael W. Young for their discoveries of molecular mechanisms controlling the circadian rhythm.

 

Option D. Discovery that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2012 was awarded to John B. Gurdon and Shinya Yamanaka for the discovery that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immune checkpoint inhibitors function by blocking the proteins that control the immune system's reactions to cancer cells. The immune system's brake is removed when these proteins are inhibited, making it easier for T cells to more efficiently eliminate cancer cells.

 

James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjo were awarded the 2018 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for their discovery of cancer therapy through inhibition of negative immune regulation.

choices.text: The quantity of sperms
The motility of sperms
The morphology of sperms
The number of sperm

questions.text: Identify the best parameter to assess in case of male infertility? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The morphology of sperms

 

Explanation:

 

The morphology of sperms is considered the best parameter to assess male infertility. Sperm morphology refers to the size and shape of sperm, and abnormalities in these characteristics can significantly affect a man's fertility.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Sperm Morphology: Characterization of normal sperm morphology shows improved correlation with fertilization rates during IVF cycles. A significantly decreased fertilization rate is observed when the normal morphology of the sample falls below the strict criteria of 4%.
  • Sperm Quantity and Number: While the quantity and number of sperms are important, they are not as critical as morphology in determining fertility potential.
  • Sperm Motility: Motility is also a crucial factor, but morphology has a stronger correlation with fertilization success.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The quantity of sperms: Refers to the total volume of ejaculate, which is less indicative of fertility compared to morphology.

 

Option B. The motility of sperms: Important for fertility but not as strongly correlated with fertilization success as morphology.

 

Option D. The number of sperm: Similar to the quantity, the number is important but does not correlate as closely with fertilization rates as morphology does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sperm morphology is the most significant parameter for assessing male infertility, as it closely correlates with fertilization rates during assisted reproductive techniques like IVF.

questions.text: A patient suffering from Bronchial asthma comes to you in hospital. All of the following drugs are used in acute exacerbation; EXCEPT: (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Leukotriene antagonist

 

Leukotriene antagonists, such as montelukast, are typically used as long-term, controller medications in asthma and are not usually used in the acute setting. They work by blocking the effects of leukotrienes, which are substances in the body that cause inflammation and constriction of airways in asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nebulization by Salbutamol: Salbutamol, a short-acting β2 agonist (SABA), is commonly used in the acute management of asthma exacerbations. It works by relaxing bronchial smooth muscle, thereby relieving bronchospasm. Nebulization is an effective method of delivery during an acute asthma attack.

 

Option B. Oxygen Therapy: Oxygen therapy is crucial in the management of acute asthma exacerbations, especially if there is evidence of hypoxemia. Asthma exacerbations can lead to significant reductions in oxygenation, and supplemental oxygen is used to maintain adequate oxygen saturation.

 

Option C. IV Magnesium Sulphate: Intravenous magnesium sulphate is used as an adjunct therapy in severe asthma exacerbations, particularly when the response to initial treatment is inadequate. Magnesium has bronchodilating and anti-inflammatory effects, making it beneficial in severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leukotriene antagonists are not typically used in the acute management of asthma exacerbations but are instead used as long-term controller medications.

questions.text: A young boy with a history of multiple blood transfusions presents with bone pain for the past 6 months. A peripheral smear showed sickle-shaped RBCs. Which of the following drugs are not used in the treatment of his condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bebtelovimab

 

  • The given clinical features are suggestive of Sickle cell anemia. Voxelotor, hydroxyurea and L-glutamine are used for treatment of sickle cell anemia whereas Bebtelovimab is not used in in this condition.
  • Bebtelovimab is a new monoclonal antibody used for the treatment of COVID-19. It works by binding to the spike protein of the COVID-19 virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Voxelotor: Is an inhibitor of hemoglobin S polymerase and stabilizer of sickle cell hemoglobin (HbS) that is used in the therapy of sickle cell disease.

 

Option C. Hydroxyurea: Improves fetal hemoglobin (HbF) and is the primary drug for controlling HbS in sickle cell disease. Thus, improving the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.

 

Option D. L-glutamine: Is a naturally occurring amino acid with antioxidant properties. It increases the availability of reduced glutathione which may lessen oxidative damage in sickle red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bebtelovimab is not used in the treatment of sickle cell anemia; it is a monoclonal antibody used for COVID-19 treatment. In contrast, Voxelotor, Hydroxyurea, and L-glutamine are used in managing sickle cell anemia by improving hemoglobin function and reducing oxidative stress in red blood cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for scrub typhus? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Doxycycline

 

Scrub typhus is a rickettsial infection caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. The main agent of choice in its treatment is Doxycycline. In pregnancy, as doxycycline is contraindicated, Azithromycin or Chloramphenicol can be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Azithromycin: Azithromycin is an alternative treatment for scrub typhus, especially in pregnant women where doxycycline is contraindicated. However, it is not the first-line treatment.

 

Option C. Chloramphenicol: Chloramphenicol can be used as an alternative treatment for scrub typhus. It is effective but less commonly used due to potential severe side effects like bone marrow suppression.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is not typically used for the treatment of scrub typhus. It is more commonly used for bacterial infections, particularly those caused by gram-negative bacteria.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Doxycycline is the drug of choice for scrub typhus due to its high efficacy in treating this rickettsial infection. Azithromycin and chloramphenicol can be used as alternatives in cases where doxycycline is contraindicated, such as during pregnancy.

questions.text: An elderly man with diabetic nephropathy presented to the emergency department with palpitations and chest discomfort. The ECG revealed large T-waves. Laboratory tests revealed elevated potassium levels. Which of the following drugs can cause intracellular movement of potassium? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epinephrine

 

Beta 2 agonists (like Salbutamol and Epinephrine) and Insulin help in the intracellular movement of K+. These drugs therefore can decrease serum potassium levels.

 

The drugs that can be used in the management of acute hyperkalemia are:

 

  • Salbutamol
  • Glucose + Insulin (DOC)
  • Calcium gluconate

 

In case of chronic hyperkalemia, K+ binding resins like Patiromer and Polystyrene sulfonate can be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucagon: Glucagon primarily works to increase blood glucose levels by promoting glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. It does not play a significant role in shifting potassium intracellularly.

 

Option C. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that blocks muscarinic receptors. It is not involved in potassium homeostasis or its intracellular movement.

 

Option D. Lactic acid: Lactic acid does not facilitate the intracellular movement of potassium. In fact, metabolic acidosis (which can be associated with elevated lactic acid levels) tends to cause potassium to move out of cells into the extracellular space, exacerbating hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-2 agonists, such as Epinephrine, are effective in promoting the intracellular movement of potassium, thereby reducing serum potassium levels in cases of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A patient was started on antihypertensive drugs. Few days later, the patient presented with the following picture. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lisinopril

 

The given picture is suggestive of angioedema. The antihypertensive drug that can lead to the development of angioedema is ACE-Inhibitors – Lisinopril in the given option. Angioedema caused by ACE inhibitors is a class effect, and patients who experience this side effect should not be given any other ACE inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nifedipine: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension and angina. It can cause side effects such as headache, flushing, and peripheral edema, but it is not typically associated with angioedema.

 

Option C. Atenolol: Atenolol is a beta-blocker used to treat hypertension and other cardiovascular conditions. Its common side effects include bradycardia, fatigue, and cold extremities, but it does not cause angioedema.

 

Option D. Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to treat hypertension. It can cause side effects such as dry mouth, sedation, and rebound hypertension upon abrupt withdrawal, but it is not associated with angioedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Side effects of ACE-Inhibitors are:-

 

  • Angioedema
  • Cough
  • Taste disturbances (Dysguesia)
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Hyperkalemia
  • They are contraindicated in Pregnancy and in patients with B/L Renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing treatment for cancer with methotrexate. What is the mechanism of action? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibits dihydrofolic acid reductase

 

Methotrexate works by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolic acid reductase (DHFR). DHFR is crucial in converting dihydrofolic acid to tetrahydrofolic acid, a necessary cofactor in DNA synthesis. By blocking DHFR, methotrexate prevents the production of tetrahydrofolic acid, ultimately disrupting DNA synthesis and cell division. This makes it effective against rapidly dividing cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibits DNA gyrase: DNA gyrase is an enzyme involved in DNA replication and repair. While inhibiting it would also disrupt cell division, it is not the primary target of methotrexate.

 

Option B. Inhibits topoisomerase II: Topoisomerase II is another enzyme involved in DNA replication. It is targeted by some anticancer drugs, but not methotrexate.

 

Option D. Alkylates DNA: Alkylating agents work by directly damaging DNA, leading to cell death. Methotrexate does not alkylate DNA; its action is more indirect through inhibiting DHFR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite drug that inhibits dihydrofolic acid reductase, an enzyme crucial for DNA synthesis. This mechanism disrupts cell division, making it effective in treating cancer.

a, b and c only
